entry.title: Creating a Time Tracking App With Meteor
entry.content:
This is a tutorial for developers meeting Meteor for the first time. We’ll develop a simple time tracking application.

Since this tutorial is to learn how to develop a web app with Meteor, we won’t build a list of requirements upfront and implement all features taking into account how each piece of code can be extended to implement other future functionalities. We’ll focus on a feature at a time instead, writing the code that’s strictly required to make that feature work. Let’s say it’s a TDD approach, but without the test part, or Feature-driven development if you prefer.

What’s meteor

If you are reading this tutorial, I presume you already know what meteor is. The official website defines it as

an open-source platform for building top-quality web apps in a fraction of the time, whether you’re an expert developer or just getting started

My own definition istead is:

Meteor is the evolution of web development, where the server joins the client, shortcutting their distance, and making reactivity the most predonimant verb

The toolset

We just need a few tools:

  • meteor
  • an editor (pick your favorite one)
  • a browser

I expect you to have meteor already installed… just in case, here’s how:

console Installing meteor curl https://install.meteor.com | /bin/sh

Once that is done, we’re ready to start.

First steps

Just to acquire confidence, let’s write a simple “Hello browser” just to be sure that everything is running and is connected.

The first thing to do is creating the meteor app, as simple as opening a terminal, navigating to the desired folder and running

console Creating Meteor app meteor create time-tracker

This creates an app skeleton, with just 3 files: css, html and js. It is already an app that can be run by typing meteor:

```sh Running meteor

meteor => Started proxy. => Started MongoDB.
=> Started your app.

=> App running at: http://localhost:3000/ ```

and accessed by just pointing the browser to http://localhost:3000/ (or whatever reported by the meteor log). The expected output is the classical Hello World page

Just to prove it’s a dynamic app and not a static html, open up the time-tracker.html page, replace Hello World! with Hello Browser! and save. The page shown in the browser automatically refreshes to reflect the new content, with no need to reload.
